content.webTitle: The path to war: how Blair battled to the brink

fields.headline: How Blair battled to the brink
fields.bodyText: 2 October 2001 At Labour Party Conference, Tony Blair tells Taliban to 'surrender the terrorists or surrender power'. Five days later the US and Britain begin air strikes against Afghanistan. 8 September 2002 Cements relationship with George W. Bush at Camp David. Persuades him to take the UN path to challenging Saddam, relying on a single new UN resolution authorising force if Iraq refuses to disarm. 24 September 2002 Presents 50-page dossier to Parliament: 'If you don't trust this dossier as a basis for continuing the military build-up, you will end up having to trust Saddam.' 8 November 2002 Blair's diplomacy triumphs as resolution 1441 is unanimously agreed at UN. 6 February 2003 Survives grilling on Newsnight by Jeremy Paxman, who asks if he prays with Dubya, in programme recorded just prior to release of second, 'dodgy', dossier of reasons to go to war, which is immediately discredited as a 'cut-and-paste' thesis lifted from the net. 15 February 2003 At Labour's spring conference in Glasgow, he appeals for support for moral case for removing Saddam and receives standing ovation. Commits himself to persevering with the UN route for as long as possible. Meanwhile, London sees its largest demonstration as more than a million march in opposition to war. 26 February 2003 Faces Party rebellion in Commons as 121 Labour MPs and all Lib Dems vote in favour of anti-war amendment. 9 March 2003 Is accused of reckless behaviour by International Development Secretary and Cabinet member Clare Short, who tells BBC Radio 4's Westminster Hour she will resign if the Government abandons the UN route. 11 March 2003 Is slow-handclapped on ITV1's Tonight with Trevor McDonald when he tries to explain his position on war with Iraq to an audience of women. 13 March 2003 Leader of the House Robin Cook hints that he will resign from the Government if Britain embarks on war without a second UN resolution.
